The Management vs Bharat Petroleum Workers Union on 25 September, 2014

:JUDGMENT

V. RAMASUBRAMANIAN, J.

This appeal arises out of an order passed by a learned Judge, allowing a writ petition filed by the workers Union directing the Government to make a reference of an Industrial Dispute raised by them for an adjudication by the Central Industrial Tribunal.

2. We have heard Mr. G. Masilamani, learned Senior Counsel appearing for the Appellant and M/s. D. Geetha, learned counsel appearing for the first Respondent, Mr. K.K.Senthilvelan, learned Assistant Solicitor General ? I, appearing for the respondents 2 and 3 and Mr. Anbusaravanan, learned counsel appearing for the fourth respondent.

3. The first respondent is a Trade Union registered under the Trade Unions Act, 1953. It is affiliated with the General Workers Union (CITU). The first Respondent Union raised an Industrial Dispute on behalf of about 29 workers, employed as Contract Workers through the fourth respondent herein, in the Tuticorin branch of the Appellant herein, seeking regularization of the services of the Contract Workers. The Assistant Commissioner of Labour (Central) initiated Conciliation Proceedings, bu the same ended in failure. Therefore, he submitted a Failure Report on 26.09.2007 to the Government of India. By a letter dated 4.12.2007, the Government of India refused to refer the dispute for adjudication, on the ground that the matter can be taken up with the Contract Labour Advisory Board by the first Respondent Union under Section 10(2) of the Contract Labour (Regulation and Abolition) Act, 1970.

4. Challenging the order of the Government dated 4.12.2007 refusing to refer the dispute for adjudication, the first respondent Union filed a writ petition in W.P.No.6928 of 2008. An objection was raised by the Appellant herein that the first Respondent Union was not a registered body and that therefore, the writ petition was not maintainable. In view of the said objection, the first Respondent Union took steps to get it registered and withdrew the writ petition with liberty. After registration of the Union, the first respondent filed a writ petition in W.P.(MD)No.6676 of 2009, challenging the order of rejection dated 4.12.2007 and also seeking a consequential direction to refer the dispute for adjudication.

5. By a final order dated 16.03.2012, K.Chandru, J allowed the writ petition, on the short ground that Section 10(2) of Contract Labour (Regulation and Abolition) Act 1970 was not a bar for raising an Industrial Dispute. The learned Judge accordingly directed the Government to consider the case of the petitioner Union afresh, in accordance with law. Aggrieved by the said order of the learned Judge, the Management is on appeal before us.

6. Mr. G. Masilamani, learned Senior Counsel appearing for the appellant, assailed the order of the learned Judge on the following grounds:

(i) That when there was no relationship of Employer and Employee between the appellant and those 29 workmen, there was no possibility for making a reference ;
(ii) That the order of the appropriate Government refusing to make a reference was only an administrative order and not a Judicial or Quasi-

Judicial order and hence, the scope of Judicial Review of such order is extremely circumscribed;

(iii) That the Union was actually blowing hot and cold, by going before the Advisory Board under the Contract Labour Act and also raising an Industrial Dispute as against the Contractor for the termination of the employees.

7. We have carefully considered the above submissions. The first ground of attack to the order of the learned Judge is that when there was no relationship of Employer and Employee between the appellant and the workers whose cause was sought to be espoused by the first respondent Union, there is no dispute much less Industrial Dispute warranting any adjudication. This is why, according to the learned Senior Counsel, the Government refused to make a reference.

8. But, we do not agree with the learned Senior Counsel for the appellant. The question as to whether a relationship of Employer and Employee exists between the two, is actually a question of fact. It is not open to the appropriate Government to adjudicate upon it, even before making a reference. It could be seen from the representation made by the first respondent Union to the Assistant Commissioner of Labour (Central), that they specifically pleaded that the appellant was the principal employer and various persons acted as immediate employers in the past. Though the Contractors, who acted as immediate employers, get changing, the workforce namely these 29 workers remained the same. This was the specific case of the first respondent Union. Therefore, the first respondent contended that the contracts were noting but smokescreen created by the appellant Management to create an illusion as though those 29 workers were Contract Labourers.

9. When the specific case of the Trade Union was that the Contract Labour System was sham and nominal and that the appellant Management was obliged to absorb those persons into their regular Pay Rolls, it cannot be contended that the existence of the relationship could be decided even without making reference. Hence, the first contention of the appellant that there was no relationship of Employer and Employee has to be rejected. Once there is specific pleading that the contract system was used to camouflage relationship, the question of existence of the relationship becomes a question of fact, which can be adjudicated only upon taking evidence.

10. The second ground of attack tot he order of the learned Judge is that the decision of the appropriate Government not to refer the dispute for adjudication is an administrative order and that therefore, it does not warrant a close scrutiny.

11. It is true that the order making a reference or refusing to make a reference is an administrative order. It is for the very same reason that the appropriate Government cannot come to any conclusion about the entitlement of the workers to any relief or not. All that the appropriate Government is obliged to do in cases of this nature is only to see whether there was an Industrial Dispute in existence or not. But what the appellant wants the Government to see is as to whether the workmen in this case can seek reliefs that they sought or not.

12. In Shaw Wallace & Company Limited ..Vs.. State of Tamil Nadu [ (1987) 1 L.L.J. 177], a Division Bench of this Court elicited the principles on the basis of which the appropriate Government should take a decision. Paragraph 32 of the said decision reads as follows:-

32. On a final analysis, the following principles emerge :-
(1) The Government would normally refer the dispute for adjudication;
(2) The Government may refuse to make reference, if -
(a) the claim is very state;
(b) the claim is opposed to the provisions of the Act;
(c) the claim is inconsistent with any agreement between the parties;
(d) the claim is patently frivolous;
(e) the impact of the claim on the general relations between the employer and the employees in the region is likely to be adverse;
(f) the person concerned is not a workman as defined by the Act;
(3) The Government should not act on irrelevant and extraneous considerations;
(4) The Government should act honestly and bona fide; (5) The Government should not embark on adjudication of the dispute; and (6) The Government should not refuse reference on the ground that domestic enquiry was fairly and properly held and punishment awarded was appropriate."

13. In paragraph 34 of the very same decision, the Division Bench pointed out that the question whether a person is a workman as defined by the Act or not, has to be decided only on the basis of the nature of the duties attached to his office or the powers vested in him and that this question cannot be decided by the Government.

14. Therefore this Court has to test as to whether an order of the appropriate Government making or refusing to make a reference, is valid or not, on the basis of the principles set out in the case of Shaw Wallace Company.

15. In Secretary, Indian Tea Association v. Ajit Kumar Barat [(2000) 3 Supreme Court Cases 93], the Court referred to an earlier decision in Prem Kakar v. State of Haryana [(1976) 3 SCC 433], wherein it was held that the order of the Government under Section 10(1) read with Section 12(5) of the Industrial Disputes Act, passed after subjective satisfaction, is an administrative order and not a judicial or a Quasi-judicial one. Therefore, the Court pointed out that once the Government had passed a reasoned order after subjective satisfaction, the Court cannot sit on appeal over the same. Eventually, the law on the point was summarized in para 7 of decision reported in Indian Tea Association as follows:-

"7. The law on the point may briefly be summarized as follows :
1. The appropriate Government would not be justified in making a reference under Section 10 of the Act without satisfying itself on the facts and circumstances brought to its notice that an industrial dispute exists or apprehended and if such a reference is made it is desirable wherever possible, for the government to indicate the nature of dispute in the order of reference;
2. The order of the appropriate Government making a reference under Section 10 of the Act is an administrative order and not a judicial or quasi-judicial one and court, therefore, cannot canvass the order of the reference closely to see if there was any material before the Government to support its conclusion, as if it was a judicial or quasi judicial order;
3. An order made by the appropriate government under Section 10 of the Act being an administrative order no lis is involved, as such an order is made on the subjective satisfaction of the Government;
4. If it appears from the reasons given that the appropriate govern-ment took into account any consideration irrelevant or foreign material, the court may in a given case consider the case for a writ of mandamus and;

5, It would, however, be open to a party to show that what was referred by the Government was not an industrial dispute within the meaning of the Act".

16. But the aforesaid decision, may not be of any assistance to the appellant, for the simple reason that the order of refusal dated 4.12.2007 passed by the Government of India was not on the basis that there was no relationship of Employer and Employee. The order dated 4.12.2007 reads as follows:-

"I am directed to refer to the Failure of Conciliation Report No.M.8/75/2007-A/M dated 26/09/2007 from the ALC(MADURAI) received in this Ministry on 15/10/2007 on the above mentioned subject and to say that, prima facie, this Ministry does not consider this dispute fit for adjudication for the following reasons:
"Since the matter relates to abolition as well as absorption of contract labour, the Union can take up the matter with the Contract Labour Advisory Board under Section 10(2) of the Contract Labour (Regulation & Abolition) Act, 1970".

17. Moreover, the test for determining whether the reference of a dispute is valid or not, are slightly different from the test for determining whether a refusal to refer is bad or not. The refusal to refer, strickes at the very root of the entitlement of both parties to have a dispute finally adjudicated by a competent forum. But, an order of reference merely ignites a process of adjudication without causing any harm or prejudice to any one of the parties. Therefore, it is neither good to confer a power upon the Government to pre-adjudicate the matter nor to shrink the power of Judicial Review on the ground that the decision of the Government is only administrative in nature and it cannot be interfered with. Hence, the second contention of the appellant is also rejected.

18. The third ground of attack to the order of the learned Judge revolves around the petition submitted by the first respondent Union to the Contract Labour Advisory Board and an Industrial Dispute already raised against the Contractor.

19. It appears that the first respondent Union made a representation dated 18.07.2005 to the Government of India, requesting the Government to prohibit the employment of Contract Labour under Section 10(1) of the Contract Labour (Regulation & Abolition) Act 1970. The Government of India forwarded the said representation to the Regional Labour Commissioner (Central) on 04.01.2006, calling upon him to verify the claim of the Union and to furnish a personal report.

20. There was also a settlement reached between the 4th Respondent herein and some of the Contract Workmen under Section 18(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. In addition, there were also settlements under Section 12(3) of the Act. Similarly, an Industrial Dispute had been raised under Section 2A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 in I.D.No.6 of 2009 before the Central Government Industrial Tribunal, about the validity of the termination of the services of some employees who were appointed as Contract Labours. The Central Government Industrial Tribunal passed an Award in the said dispute on 18.07.2011 holding that the appellant Corporation was not answerable to the claim.

21. Therefore, on the basis of the (1) representation made under the Contract Labour (Regulation & Abolition) Act 1970, (2) the Settlements reached under Section 18(1) and 12(3) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 with the Contractors and (3) the Award passed by the Central Government Industrial Tribunal in I.D.No.6 of 2009, it is contended by Mr. G. Masilamani, learned Senior Counsel for the appellant that there is no question of referring the present dispute for adjudication.

22. However, as rightly pointed out by M/s. D. Geetha, learned counsel appearing for the first respondent Union, we are not concerned here with the validity of the claim of the first Respondent Union. We are only concerned with the entitlement of the first Respondent Union to have the dispute referred for adjudication.

23. In Steel Authority of India v. National Union Waterfront Workers [(2001) 7 Supreme Court Cases 1], the Supreme Court explained the concept of the term "Contract Labour". It was held in paragraph 71 of the said report that a workman may be hired in an establishment by the principal employer or by his agent with or without the knowledge of the principal employer. He may also be hired in connection with the work of an establishment by the principal employer through a contractor or by a contractor with or without the knowledge of the principal employer. Where a workman is hired in or in connection with the work of an establishment by the principal employer through a contractor, he merely acts as an "agent" so that there will be "master-and-servant" relationship between the principal employer and the workman.

24. In para 97 of the decision in Steel Authority of India, the Supreme Court referred to the earlier decision in R.K.Panda v. Steel Authority of India, in which the Supreme Court found that the same workers were engaged by changing contractors. Therefore, the Court held that the question whether the contract labours had become the workers of the principal employer in a course of time or not had to be established on the basis of the requisite material before the Labour Court or Industrial Tribunal. In para 102 of the same decision, the Supreme Court held that if the so-called contract is a sham and camouflage to hide the reality, Section 10 would not apply and the workmen can raise an industrial dispute for the very same relief with which they have now come in this Court. The Bench referred to the decision in Air India case [(1997) 9 SCC 377], which modified the decision in Gujaraj Electricity Board case [(1995) 5 SCC 27] and came to the conclusion that the Labour Court or Industrial adjudicator would have jurisdiction to entertain the said dispute.

25. In paragraph 125 of the report, the Supreme Court actually summarized the position that evolved out of the discussions. In sub para (3) of para 125, the Supreme Court indicated that Section 10 of the Contract Labour (Regulation & Abolition) Act does not provide for automatic absorption. In sub para (5), the Supreme Court held that the Industrial adjudicator will have to consider whether the contractor has been interposed to produce any given result or as a mere ruse/camouflage to evade compliance with various beneficial legislations.

26. In the light of the law so well laid down by the Supreme Court in Steel Authority of India Limited, we do not think that the representation made under the Contract Labour Act or the settlements reached with the contractors would destroy a statutory remedy available to the workmen at least to have their dispute heard and adjudicated by a competent forum. Therefore, the third ground of attack to the decision of the learned Judge also deserves to be dismissed.

27. Relying upon the decision of the Supreme Court in Rashtriya Chemicals v. General Employees' Association [(2007) 5 Supreme Court Cases 273], it is contended by Mr. G. Masilamani, learned Senior Counsel for the appellant that a Court cannot straightaway direct the Government to refer the dispute for adjudication. But we do not know why the said decision is sought to be relied upon. In the case on hand, the learned Judge merely set aside the order of refusal of the Government to refer the dispute with the Industrial Tribunal and remitted the matter back for effective consideration. In the operative portion of the order, the learned Judge merely directed the Government to consider the case afresh and take a decision within 8 weeks. Therefore, there is no cause for any complaint that the learned Judge overstepped the jurisdiction conferred upon him.

28. In fine, we do not find any justification to interfere with the order of the learned Judge. Hence, the writ appeal is dismissed. The appropriate Government, who is the second Respondent herein, is directed to consider the representation of the first Respondent Union and take a decision and communicate the same to both parties within a period of 8 weeks from the date of receipt of copy of this order. No costs. Consequently, M.P.No.1 of 2012 is closed. 

(V.R.S., J.)     (V.M.V., J.)
